content.title: Cardiac Magnetic Resonance Imaging (CMR)
content.summary: Cardiac MRI is a non-invasive imaging modality that uses magnetic fields and radiofrequency pulses to produce detailed images of cardiac anatomy, function, tissue characterization, and perfusion without ionizing radiation. It is considered the gold standard for ventricular volumetric assessment and myocardial tissue characterization.
key_points: Gold standard for LV and RV volume and ejection fraction quantification
Late gadolinium enhancement (LGE) identifies scar and fibrosis patterns
T1 and T2 mapping enable detection of edema, fibrosis, and infiltrative diseases
Stress perfusion CMR detects ischemia with high sensitivity and specificity
Essential for arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy and cardiac masses evaluation
Contraindicated with non-MRI-compatible devices and severe renal impairment (eGFR <30)
content.statement: Cardiac MRI provides unparalleled tissue characterization and functional assessment, enabling precise diagnosis of cardiomyopathies, ischemic heart disease, congenital heart disease, and cardiac masses through sequences including cine imaging, LGE, T1/T2 mapping, and stress perfusion.

explanation.intuition: CMR works by aligning hydrogen protons in the body using a strong magnetic field, then perturbing them with radiofrequency pulses. Different tissues relax at different rates, creating contrast. Gadolinium accumulates in areas of expanded extracellular space (scar, fibrosis), appearing bright on LGE images.
explanation.key_insight: The pattern of late gadolinium enhancement is pathognomonic for different conditions: subendocardial/transmural LGE indicates infarction; mid-wall LGE suggests non-ischemic cardiomyopathy; epicardial LGE indicates myocarditis or sarcoidosis.
explanation.technical_details: Standard CMR protocol includes: (1) Localizers and scout images, (2) Cine imaging in multiple planes for function, (3) T2-weighted images for edema, (4) Native T1 mapping, (5) Early gadolinium enhancement for thrombus, (6) Late gadolinium enhancement 10-15 min post-contrast, (7) T1 mapping post-contrast for ECV calculation.

definitions_glossary.late_gadolinium_enhancement: Delayed imaging 10-15 minutes after gadolinium administration showing areas of myocardial scar or fibrosis as hyperintense regions
definitions_glossary.t1_mapping: Quantitative technique measuring longitudinal relaxation time of myocardium, elevated in fibrosis and amyloidosis, reduced in iron overload and Fabry disease
definitions_glossary.t2_mapping: Quantitative assessment of transverse relaxation time, elevated in myocardial edema from acute inflammation or infarction
definitions_glossary.extracellular_volume_fraction: ECV calculated from pre- and post-contrast T1 values, quantifies interstitial expansion in fibrosis and amyloidosis
definitions_glossary.cine_imaging: Steady-state free precession (SSFP) sequences providing dynamic assessment of wall motion and ventricular function
definitions_glossary.stress_perfusion: First-pass gadolinium imaging during vasodilator stress (adenosine, regadenoson) to detect inducible ischemia
definitions_glossary.myocardial_viability: Assessment of potential for functional recovery post-revascularization based on scar transmurality
definitions_glossary.gadolinium_chelates: Paramagnetic contrast agents (gadoterate, gadobutrol) that shorten T1 relaxation and accumulate in expanded extracellular space
definitions_glossary.phase_contrast_imaging: Velocity-encoded sequences for flow quantification through valves and great vessels
definitions_glossary.4d_flow: Time-resolved 3D phase-contrast imaging enabling comprehensive hemodynamic assessment
definitions_glossary.strain_imaging: Feature tracking analysis of myocardial deformation from cine images
definitions_glossary.dark_blood_imaging: T1-weighted sequences with blood signal suppression for morphological assessment

pathophysiology.mechanism: CMR exploits the magnetic properties of hydrogen protons in water and fat. T1 relaxation (spin-lattice) and T2 relaxation (spin-spin) differ between normal and pathological tissue. Gadolinium contrast shortens T1, accumulating in areas with expanded extracellular space due to myocyte loss, fibrosis, or edema.
key_pathways: Magnetic alignment of hydrogen protons in strong magnetic field
Radiofrequency pulse excitation and subsequent relaxation
Tissue-specific T1 and T2 relaxation times
pathophysiology.clinical_significance: Enables differentiation of ischemic from non-ischemic cardiomyopathies, detection of subclinical disease, prognostication, and guidance of therapy including revascularization and device implantation decisions.

imaging_findings.ischemic_cardiomyopathy: Subendocardial or transmural LGE in coronary distribution
imaging_findings.dilated_cardiomyopathy: Mid-wall septal LGE, diffuse fibrosis on T1 mapping
imaging_findings.hypertrophic_cardiomyopathy: Patchy mid-wall LGE at RV insertion points
imaging_findings.cardiac_amyloidosis: Difficulty nulling myocardium, elevated native T1, high ECV
imaging_findings.myocarditis: Epicardial or mid-wall LGE, elevated T2 (edema)
imaging_findings.arvc: RV dilation, fatty infiltration, RV wall motion abnormalities

clinical_applications: Guide revascularization decisions based on viability (>50% transmural scar predicts no recovery)
Risk stratification for sudden cardiac death (LGE extent predicts arrhythmia)
Monitor treatment response in myocarditis and sarcoidosis
Assess iron chelation efficacy in thalassemia

decision_thresholds.viability: Segments with <50% transmural LGE likely to recover function post-revascularization
decision_thresholds.scd_risk: LGE extent >15% of LV mass associated with increased arrhythmic risk in non-ischemic cardiomyopathy
decision_thresholds.iron_overload: T2* <20ms indicates iron overload; <10ms indicates severe overload requiring intensified chelation

skos.definition: A non-invasive diagnostic imaging technique using magnetic fields and radiofrequency pulses to create detailed images of cardiac structure, function, and tissue characteristics without ionizing radiation

learning_objectives: Explain the physical principles underlying cardiac MRI including T1 and T2 relaxation
Describe the standard CMR protocol components and their clinical applications
Interpret late gadolinium enhancement patterns to differentiate ischemic from non-ischemic cardiomyopathies
Apply CMR findings to clinical decision-making for revascularization and device therapy
Identify contraindications to CMR and gadolinium administration
Recognize CMR findings in specific cardiomyopathies including HCM, DCM, ARVC, and cardiac amyloidosis
clinical_pearls: The pattern of LGE is key: subendocardial = ischemic; mid-wall = non-ischemic; epicardial = myocarditis
Difficulty nulling the myocardium on LGE suggests cardiac amyloidosis
Native T1 is elevated in amyloidosis and fibrosis, but reduced in Fabry disease and iron overload
Segments with >50% transmural scar will not recover function after revascularization
T2* <20ms indicates cardiac iron overload; <10ms requires urgent treatment
MR-conditional pacemakers/ICDs are safe at 1.5T with appropriate protocols

specialty_boards.cardiology: High yield - detailed protocol knowledge, pattern recognition, clinical integration
specialty_boards.radiology: High yield - sequence optimization, artifact recognition, comprehensive reporting

common_misconceptions: All pacemakers are absolute contraindications (many modern devices are MR-conditional)
CMR cannot assess coronary arteries (coronary MRA is possible though limited)
Stress CMR requires exercise (vasodilator stress is standard)
